awd_abstract_narration:
The theory of C*-algebras was invented in the 1930s and 1940s as a mathematical model for quantum mechanics. In addition to their connections with physics, C*-algebras provide a useful framework for studying a variety of mathematical objects. Applications of C*-algebras beyond physics are also beginning to arise; for example, one can use C*-algebras to study both quantum information theory, and directed graphs, or networks. Conversely, the C*-algebras associated to directed graphs have proved to be key examples which have enhanced our understanding of the class of C*-algebras as a whole. This project focuses on a generalization of directed graphs -- higher-rank graphs -- and their associated C*-algebras. A better understanding of the C*-algebras associated to higher-rank graphs will strengthen our understanding of C*-algebras as a whole, and also their applicability to other areas of mathematics. In addition to involving graduate and undergraduate students in research about higher-rank graph C*-algebras, this project will also enhance the intellectual opportunities available to mathematicians at the University of Montana and at nearby universities, in two ways. First, it initiates an exchange program for research-level graduate students at the University of Montana, to enable them to spend a semester studying at a university which is offering an advanced graduate course or seminar that complements the student's research interests. Second, the principal investigator will host national and international research scholars at the University of Montana, and will facilitate these scholars' visits to other regional institutions during their stay in Montana.

Higher-rank graphs were introduced by Kumjian and Pask in 2000, in the hopes that their associated C*-algebras, like graph C*-algebras, would provide important insights about C*-algebras more generally. However, the structure of higher-rank graph C*-algebras is much more intricate than that of graph C*-algebras, and this complexity has limited the applicability of higher-rank graph C*-algebras to other areas of mathematics up to now. To reverse this trend, this project will (1) improve our ability to recognize higher-rank graph C*-algebras in other contexts; and (2) develop new, stronger tools for analyzing higher-rank graph C*-algebras. Towards the first goal, the principal investigator will clarify the relationship between higher-rank graph C*-algebras and their twisted counterparts, as well as investigate connections between higher-rank graph C*-algebras and other branches of mathematics (such as Lie algebras and lattices, and wavelets and multiresolution analyses). The second goal will be achieved by studying invariants of higher-rank graph C*-algebras such as their K-theory, groupoid structure, KMS states, and Cartan subalgebras.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

The research supported by this grant focused on the C*-algebras associated to higher-rank graphs and related objects.   Our understanding of these C*-algebras was strengthened in the following areas:

-   How can one change a higher-rank graph without changing the associated C*-algebra?

  • Under the PI’s direction, four student research teams investigated this question.  The results have led to one publication (Eckhardt et al, “Moves on k-graphs preserving Morita equivalence,” Canad. J. Math. 2020) and two preprints in preparation.
  • S.J. Lippert (who earned his PhD in 2023 under the PI’s direction) also investigated this question in his PhD thesis. These results have been accepted for publication in Houston J. Math.

-   The real C*-algebras of higher-rank graphs:

  • In joint work with J. Boersema (Annals of K-Theory 2022), the PI developed a spectral sequence for computing the K-theory of the real C*-algebra of a higher-rank graph with involution.
  • With S. Browne and J. Boersema (Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 2024), the PI identified the stable exotic Cuntz algebra as the real C*-algebra of a rank-3 graph with involution.  The existence of the stable exotic Cuntz algebra was proved abstractly in 2011 by Boersema, Ruiz, and Stacey, but a concrete model for it was unknown until now.

-   When does a groupoid C*-algebra admit multiple groupoid models? In this case, how are the different groupoids related?

  • At the first Women in Operator Algebras workshop at the Banff Centre, the PI began investigating the first question with A. Duwenig, R. Norton, S. Reznikoff, and S. Wright. The results were published in J. Functional Anal. (2020).
  • The second question was answered by A. Duwenig, R. Norton, and the PI (Int. Math. Res. Not. 2022), and (in a more general setting) by J.H. Brown and the PI (arXiv preprint).

-    Williams’ conjecture for graph algebras

  • The conjecture asks when stable isomorphism is the same as K-theory equivalence for graph C*-algebras.  It is known to be false in general.
  • With L. Cordeiro, D. Goncalves, and R. Hazrat (Israel J. Math., to appear), we proved that Williams’ conjecture holds for a new class of directed graphs, which we call meteor graphs.

Other papers by the PI and coauthors have investigated the representation theory of the C*-algebras of higher-rank graphs; the K-theory of the C*-algebras of product systems; and the link between KMS states and Hausdorff dimension for higher-rank graph C*-algebras.

Broader impacts:

This grant enhanced the intellectual opportunities available at the University of Montana and strengthened the ties between the University of Montana and other nearby universities.  In addition to the colloquium and seminar lectures delivered by the PI’s collaborators during visits to the University of Montana, the grant:

-  Supported summer research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, in 2019, 2020, 2021, and 2023

  • This has been the only summer research opportunity for undergraduates at the University of Montana in the last eight years
  • Over 40% of the supported students were underrepresented minorities

-   Initiated a summer writing retreat for women in analysis in Montana and Idaho

-   Supported 3 mathematics graduate students from the University of Montana to spend a semester working with an expert at another university:

  • Ricela Feliciano-Semidei worked with Yukiko Maeda from Purdue University
  • Anastasia Halfpap worked with Joszef Balogh and the combinatorics group at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
  • Patrick Kreitzberg worked with Rufus Willett and the operator algebras group at the University of Hawai’i

-  Facilitated visits by the PI and her collaborators to other nearby universities, such as Montana Tech and Idaho State University

Furthermore, this grant enabled the PI to lead research projects at the first (2018) and second (2021) Women in Operator Algebras research collaboration workshops.  These collaborations have resulted in two published papers and one preprint in preparation, and both groups received funding (from SLMath and ICMS Edinburgh respectively) for a second in-person research collaboration.  These papers and competitive research collaboration grants have boosted the careers of eight female researchers in operator algebras, as well as the PI.

The grant also supported the PI’s involvement in the Groundwork for Operator Algebras Lecture Series (GOALS), which is an NSF-funded summer school which aims to improve recruitment and retention among graduate students in operator algebras, especially those from underrepresented backgrounds.  The PI has been an organizer and lecturer at GOALS every year since its inception in 2020, and this grant has covered her GOALS-related travel expenses.
